message: any idea how to debug http requests to a website? my problem is that i have a website that takes 2 Sec. waiting time and 175 MiliSec. Receiving. I would like to know why it's taking 2 sec. waiting time :S

data.message: im curious to know that website.. :D would u post a url?
You can use Fiddler or Chrome Speed Tracer extension
http://breezi.com
Fiddler is a great tool as Mohammed pointed out, also there is FireBug Net panel, YSlow plug-in and another more of an all-in-one solution New Relic.
Can't install Fiddler (I'm working on MAC) :S
Media Temple managed service = BAD PERFORMANCE
I know! had to upgrade from VS3 to VS4 and it's stupid process migrating everything!
I think you should consider migrating to another datacenter
big companies use them for testing purposes, not production sites.
what do you recommend ?

if you will manage your own server/VPS, go for Hetzner.com.
if you want a cloud server, stormondemand.com
for a managed server/VPS, liquidweb.com
Yeah, I will be managing the server
Hetzner.com is perfect. trust me. sites like Mawaly.com are hosted there. Check the website performance
i minimized the delay using Pragma Caching. Waiting time now is: 93ms.
u can also switch to nginx
ngnix caching?

nginx webserver... much faster
http://joeandmotorboat.com/2008/02/28/apache-vs-nginx-web-server-performance-deathmatch/
Yes, I already use it: http://d.pr/i/2j2M
One way you can do it is clear cache in chrome, open dev toolbar (F12), switch to Network panel, and open the website, see the timeline telling you what time spent on what.

Doing this, it seems to me that you have so many JS and CSS files, that are exceeding the limit of parallel downloads and had to be queued, some of the files are a bit big too (over 100K). The solution? Consider combining files together into single file in production, and maybe minify files as well.
Yes, We've passed all the limits in this website because we have videos/HD photos in the home page (I'm hosting some of them in S3 to get advantage of parallel loading).

A lot of the files I see in the network tab are CSS/JS. Not sure what technology you are using, but there must be an asset management / bundling / combination and minification framework for it. All big platforms have at least one now.
you may try Google Page speed service.. It minifies your html and combines all css/javascript

Combination in this case is even more important than minification (although it is still important), every tech stack will have something that uses google's or Yahoos or Microsoft's or something else, just get anything, and again, start with combining the files.

I see the total page size is really big, it exceeds 3MB, and it contains a lot of elements which make it very slow in browser anyway so I would load most of it asynchronously using JS/AJAX on demand when user scrolls down, this will speed up the landing time, or at least use lazy loading tricks for images
